review_title: Has its perks, but overall not great
pros: - Hybrid schedule (2 days in-office, 3 remote) + flexibility to work remotely while traveling. - My team/department respected my time outside of the 40-hr workweek. - Tuition remission, 2:1 retirement match up to 5% (total 15%). - Week off between Christmas and New Year. - AU has some great faculty and innovative programs!
cons: - Low pay relative to DC area. Need to pay for parking at AU. The retirement match is nice but doesn't do much if you're not getting paid much to begin with. - Vacation for new staff is subpar and does not include all federal holidays. - Lack of formalized onboarding/professional development programs for my department. Unclear who the points of contact were for various FAQs. Lack of cohesion in strategy between teams. - In my role, I worked alongside a certain department whose office is off-campus, but I was formally employed by one of the schools. The specifics of my (for lack of better term) "dual-employment" situation were not communicated clearly to me, which caused me a great deal of logistical trouble, as well as difficulty finding my place within the company culture. - In my experience, colleagues did not take the initiative to make new hires feel welcome. Teams/cohorts can become cliquey. It also does not help that my office does not have a designated break/lunch area for employees to socialize - making many susceptible to eating lunch at their desks and working through their unpaid lunch break. - Senior administration is anti-unionization. Staff needed to go on strike in summer 2022 for livable pay and health benefits.

review_title: Lack of support system, exploitative practices
pros: Like anywhere, some supervisors are very caring and attentive and will defend the rights of their employees. Oftentimes, team members will provide the support that upper-level management does not, and fill in the gaps for logistical mistakes made during scheduling.
cons:
There is little to no organizational transparency or accountability. The official support system for Housing and even Maintenance employees is severely lacking, leading to employee burnout, lowered efficiency, and low cohesion.
Student staff are consistently exploited and devalued, as one line on the hiring papers (dubbed the "other duties as assigned" clause) allows for upper management to add expansive tasks to the job description as seen fit. This has forced RAs to serve as: furniture movers, security guards, mail workers, therapists, and more, all under that clause. 
 On a day to day basis, it is difficult to follow up on minor issues (anything deemed low priority), and as you go up the ladder, it feels like management would rather play hot potato with serious issues rather than actually handling anything. This harms the residential student body, especially underclassmen who tend to rely on student staff (RAs) to handle all of their issues, even when those problems surpass what student staff should legally take on.

review_title: It is What You Make of It
pros: As a current police officer at American University reading the previous reviews I wanted to give a current opinion. As the title suggests this job is what you make of it. If you want amazing benefits then AU offers it. Great healthcare, 2:1 matching on 401k retirement, they will completely pay for an undergraduate degree for you or direct family members and you pay only taxes on masters degrees. Overtime is pretty abundant. There are multiple training opportunities and the ability to propose your own trainings. Uniform is professional. Contrary to previous reviews you do get EVOC trained (emergency vehicle) to drive lights and sirens. This police department is very officer friendly and while working at an extremely liberal university, still has your back. The academy training is 12-13 weeks and has improved immensely from previous years. (Start running and doing pushups NOW if you’re not already and you’re applying) You are considered a university special police officer but this still a pretty professional department where you can do some great police work if you actually put in the effort. AU is a community that really welcomes a community policing model so if you’re not interested in that, keep looking. There are opportunities for upward mobility or to get special assignments and duties such as Field training officer, background investigator, training instructor; but you have to request them and work for it (makes sense to me). For a police department this place has a great work life balance with a good amount of time off earned annually and actually available to use. Holiday pay is amazing!
cons: The pay is up to par with the rest of the universities in DC but should be higher. Starting pay without experience is $22.95/hour currently. Staffing is an issue currently but that seems to be with every police department right now. You do not carry a firearm so there is a safety concern with some situations. Higher Leadership is often prioritizing the wrong things in my opinion.

review_title: Excellent place to work, but be aware of the potential for office politics
pros: Great tuition and other benefits (generous retirement and vacation packages).  The work itself was exciting as there is a lot of energy and dedication towards moving the university forward.  It's not boring.  Most of the people were really nice and it was easy to develop friendships that went beyond the workplace.  The campus is beautiful and overall a great work location.  Lots of opportunities to get involved and make a difference.  I enjoyed working there.   An excellent place for young people, particularly those that want to get a degree while working.
cons:
The pay was bad, but the work was fulfilling and the tuition and retirement benefits usually made up for it.   

A bigger issue was the politics.  In some cases, once you were targeted by a coworker or more senior administrative official, forget it.  You would get blamed for stuff and have people sabotage you and it was a matter of getting out before you got fired.  I saw these scenarios happen multiple times in different departments across campus.  In other cases, folks who were completely ineffective or toxic received promotions (including those that had multiple complaints filed with HR against them).  It helps to know how to play the game and watch your back.  Also, generally the lower you are on the totem pole, the farther away you are from this sort of thing.

job_title: Assistant Director of Development in Washington, DC
pros:
The environment is professional, yet relaxed. Most of my coworkers are passionate about their work. While many staff members have their work email on their smartphones, many do not feel the need to check it after hours or on weekends. It mainly depends on your position, but most of the junior staff maintain a very healthy work-life balance, consisting of 7-hour work days.

The campus community is always teeming with activities to participate in to better yourself, such as professional skill building workshops and health-oriented challenges. It is very easy to get involved if you are interested, but are not pressured to do so if you'd rather not.

Great benefits (retirement, professional development, and tuition remission are the highlights). My department places a particular focus on professional development, which I appreciate.
cons:
The actual campus no longer accommodates a lot of supporting divisions for the University. It is odd to work so far from campus. 

Upward mobility can be tricky at times - I'm not sure about how long I can stay in my current position without stunting my career. I think your satisfaction as an employee here is directly related to the competency of your supervisor to be an effective manager.

We receive a large number of days off in December, but otherwise, the annual leave in your first few years is a bit stingy (one day per month for the first two years; 1.25 days off for years 2 - 5) and is a bit difficult to stretch far enough.

Parking is VERY expensive.

review_title: Working as a DR at AU is a relaxed, worthwhile experience.
pros: You're allowed to do anything at your desk as long as you've finished your tasks and no residents need help, which is a benefit that's difficult to find. I always did my homework at the desk, and I ended up never having to do it outside of work. It was like getting paid to study. You do, of course, have to fulfill the tasks for your job and help residents, but it's not too difficult and it's nice to be able to serve people with whom you can become friends. I'm a very people-oriented person, so I loved helping residents when they came to the desk. Overall, this is my favorite job so far (out of five that I've had.)
cons: Well, the hours can be crappy sometimes, since it's 24 hours. I, thankfully, did not have to ever work between the hours of 2am and 8am, but most DRs did. You're not scheduled any breaks either, but that's easy to deal with because you can leave as long as another DR or RA comes to sit at the desk (if you have to go to the bathroom or something.) Not many downsides besides the hours, and the hours can even be a plus too because the 24-hour timeframe allows for more flexibility in when you schedule your shifts.

pros: I loved working here much
cons: I dont have cons here

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Washington, DC
pros:
Work in a  liberal academic environment
Fantastic opportunities for tuition remission
Although I did take issue with the motivation issues, I did meet some genuinely nice and enthusiastic colleagues who's passion really was higher education.
cons: AU sometimes reminds me of a microcosmic of the DC government: there are processes for everything. Sometimes they worked, and sometimes they just mangled and prolonged what should be an easy process. I think the culture is the biggest problem, some employees seem very content to do the bare minimum for their jobs. Makes for a great work/life balance, but too often you saw the opportunity to truly serve the client (whether student, faculty, or an external client) and a colleague that was unwilling to go the extra mile beyond the job description. I think this stems from the idea that the student is the customer and a revenue source, instead of fostering the students' development (which is the point of a university, isn't it?)

job_title: I'd Rather Not Say. in Washington, DC
pros: I found a few good friends.  The tuition benefits are decent and my office was flexible in allowing me to do school work in the office.  I was in a point in my life where my social life was very important to me and this job allowed me to go out during the week and come in to work hungover and late.  No one cared about anything and my boss would roll in to the office about three hours after I did (daily occurrence).  Of course, I have ambition and drive so I left this office soon after I started.
cons: In my office, I found that my co-workers were unmotivated, lacked experience, and were unwilling to be honest with each other about weaknesses and strengths.  My performance review (which was supposed to be completed by me) was done by my manager because she didn't want to do her own work.  There is no accountability and no drive to be a better organization.  People could go weeks without doing any real work.  People with skill, ambition, and drive are not used in the organization or tapped for information or ideas.  Stay away if you want professional development.

review_title: Stimulating Environment; Horrible Pay and Lack of Upperlevel Support
pros: This is a really smart, progressive place to work. There was generally a creative, progressive vibe, and a willingness to try new things. Student body is manageable in size, and in my division, was pretty diverse, as was the workforce. Retirement matching was wonderful. Didn't use any other benefits, really (though spouse at another employer).
cons: I was told twice by HR that they intentionally paid undermarket. Boy, they were'nt kidding. Data driven independently (professionally!) conducted salary surveys showed that in my profession within the university, counterparts at comparable schools in the city made anywhere from $15k-$20k more for the same title, but with more staff to provide support. This made working there simply unsustainable, and it really demotivates you. The ability to move up within your pay band or to receive any type of "bonus" was non-existent. When salaries can't keep up, you don't get to keep good workers. Simple as that.  Good luck with the sky-high rate of staff turnover...!

pros: Fantastic benefits and pay package. The AU Department of Public Safety (DPS) does allow almost unlimited overtime and the benefits package provided by AU is unmatched in the private sector.
cons:
Are you looking for a real police department? This is not it. The department doesn't have EVOC for their officers and their cars aren't rated to do EVOC. The cars cant go lights and sirens on DC roads. The Officers don't carry guns or tasers. They have no general orders for some odd reason. If killed by DC code it is not "Murder of a Police Officer". The officers here lead a sad existence between having to enforce the law, and being bullied by MPD (local cops) who actually carry guns and can go lights and sirens. The Officers can't do plain clothes without express written consent from the Chief of Police.  A lot of these issues stem from the department being classified as a "Special Police" agency by DC code which limits their power greatly. 

The academy is a 2 Month joke of an academy where you learn nothing except that the other schools have is just as bad as you do.

pros: Generous benefits, if you can actually afford to use them.
cons: No work/life balance, incompetent management, the pay is significantly below market value.

review_title: Great university values, if your department believes in them
pros: Inclusive and competitive benefits, decent performance review process, diverse staff and customer/student base, emphasis on professional development, many resources, overall really smart, passionate students. It can be a great place to be if you love doing your job, IF others in your office/department feel the same way.
cons: Individual departments don't always practice what the university preaches, and take it upon themselves to pick-and-choose what's important in the university. There are amazing people at AU who love it and understand it, but if you end up with a bad manager, don't expect any real help from HR to deal with the situation.

pros:
There was a lot of room for growth, and everyone was conscientious of the fact that I was a student without a lot of work experience - they were very forgiving of mistakes and gave me lots of opportunities to learn new skills and meet new people. My supervisor was very flexible with scheduling - both working around class and schoolwork and with sick days. 

The office itself is very nice. It's a very safe area, right next to a metro, the equipment is all relatively new and easy to work with, etc.
cons: Logistically, the office itself is inconvenient to nearly everything - it's right next to a metro, but it's about 45 minutes from campus which makes scheduling difficult. The job involves a lot of routines - I liked that, but I know for some people doing the same or similar assignments every week would be a deal-breaker.

pros: Great community feel. The people who work here care about their work, each other, and the students. The University has put a lot of effort and energy into employee wellness, well-being, and recognition lately and doing a great job. Tuition remission is great as is the 2 to 1 retirement match. The campus is beautiful, too!
cons: Flex-time policy is not consistent across the university and largely dependent on your supervisor, which leads to inconsistency, frustration, and lack of trust between employees. Many managers have been here a long time and are no longer innovating--just too comfortable and thus making it VERY hard if you want to advance. It's easier to make a lateral move across campus or leave the university all together. Your best bet for a good salary is on your way in.

pros: Benefits are good, you accumulate vacation time each month.  You get 49 hours of sick leave a year for a first year employee, and some perks.
cons:
You're underpaid and the work environment for non-faculty is not great.  Faculty look through administrative staff like they're walls or part of the decor. No one says hello, and very few people are friendly.  Egos are big, so you spend a lot of time not stepping on toes.

52k isn't a lot to make a living in DC.  No commuter benefits (no paid metro, no free parking).  essentially you pay WMATA or AU to work there.  It isn't great.

Additionally, there aren't a lot of chances to move up.  Program coordinator is a ceilinged position with little pay, which doesn't encourage longevity.

review_title: Even as a student, the staff is more than willing to accommodate your needs
pros: The work-life balance was great, and even though my time as a student ended my office was willing to keep me on until I found a job. Not only that, they were more than OK with me going off to interviews. The staff in my office were great at their work and a joy to work with on projects.
cons: Inevitably for some of the higher-end positions, there is some politicking involved and some of this knowledge bleeds down to the rest of the staff and can often cause problems, especially when debating the merits of internal candidates vs. external candidates.

review_title: Administratively, not on the cutting edge
pros: They have a very nice location, a beautiful campus with top-of-the-line attractions, including the President of the United States, and they offer great benefits, including paid tuition for employees and families.  There are functions where very interesting political and other celebrities appear for speaking engagements.   The admin assistants at this institution are all very highly educated, as many had Masters degrees.
cons: Was difficult to foster change (which is typical in higher ed), communication with management in certain areas was difficult and the systems reflected old technology and were not easy to work with.  Parking was not always easy and some of the admin offices were not located geographically near one another and were not on the main campus.

pros: People are generally very willing to trade shifts with you as needed, and you can always find a way to fit work with Housing and Dining around your busy schedule. It might mean some late nights but hey, that's why you took the job in the first place.
cons: Lately it has become more difficult to get strange shift hours covered and overall has become more a hassle to work for housing and dining. Large levels of staff turnover as well as a severe lack of flexibility by those in charge have made it hard to continue working for the organization.

pros: I worked for University Communications and Marketing as a video editor for 4 years. I was able to grow professionally and improve my skills while there with a team of talented and creative people. They were always open to listening to my ideas and implementing them. I was able to get a higher position as a result of my years there. The benefits including tuition remission were also excellent.
cons: As with many places these days there weren't many opportunities  for advancement. Also I had no windows in my office.

review_title: AU is a great place to work your way through school
pros: The tuition benefit, the retirement plan and the atmosphere. It's a low-to-no-stress environment, and because most employees are also students, your managers are supportive of your needs as a student.
cons:
Most jobs are compensated for 35-hours a week, and that means you are paid 12 percent less than you would get for a 40-hour a week job. In addition, your tuition benefit goes on your W-2 as taxable income after the first $5,000+. But still the tuition benefit can be worth $20,000 a year.

The vacation time is a little low to start and you can't get into the retirement plan until you've been employed for one year.

pros: American University really cares about its employees - you see it in the total compensation, performance planning, and training opportunities. So many people go to American U to grow their careers, a smart choice. Many people have worked at AU for a long time which means building positive relationships is a key to being successful.
cons: Higher education is not for everyone. A lot of people who have tried transitioning from the corporate world have had a challenge with the consensus-driven environment. There is enormous value in working toward consensus but it can be challenging for those not accustomed or adaptive.

review_title: Great Benefits, Lower Pay, No Career Growth
pros: 2:1 matching retirement, great environment, lots of cool people; great if you just want to clock your hours in, not make much of an impact and have a work/life balance. Also, you can get tuition reimburseent.
cons: Absolutely no career growth. Staff are also treated as second class compared to faculty, which can really get annoying when they give faculty credit for your program excelling. Also, everybody has an opinion on everything and they don't yield to experts. So if you've taken one finance class, suddenly your opinion on how we should budget should be heard.

pros: Lots of varied opportunities and a great deal of faculty to work with.  The staff at AU employ a great number of Dean's Fellows at the law school from the student population, and it's a great learning experience to work alongside the school's excellent faculty.  There's a lot of competition, like all law school jobs, but the staff are knowledgeable, friendly, and eager to help you deal with a lot of the little issues that pop up from time to time.  Would definitely recommend.
cons: There's a lot of competition for positions, due to the large, talented student body, so you may end up submitting a lot of applications to a lot of faculty before you find your opportunity.

pros:
- AU offers good benefits, including a 2-to-1 match on retirement contributions and nil tied tuition remission for employees
- The office culture where I work is supportive and friendly
- Practically guaranteed raises every September
cons:
- Because the university offices are sort of compartmentalized by specialty/school, the office culture of your particular office can be very different from that f the next office, which is sometimes negative
- The "guaranteed" raises are not very big
- Not a lot of room for advancement in most offices - usually about one manager for each office, so if you want to move up without changing to a different type if job you have to wait until your manager leaves

pros:
Good supervisors: Communication and understanding between me and my supervisor was really good. 
Great colleagues: The people that work in these jobs are almost all top notch people. Would totally hang out with most of them after I leave.
cons:
Students can be extra as hell. Not everyone is on the same playing field and can be difficult to manage expectations. 
The time commitment can be overwhelming and not easy foreseen. Things come up all the time without preparation and you have to be able to manage it mostly on your own. Not anyone's fault per say but it is something to take into account.

review_title: Colleagues are great, but management is terrible
pros: Work-life balance is generally good, although certain times of the year can be overwhelming. Students are engaging and faculty very interesting. There is a prevailing ethos of service and community, although this seems to be eroding. Benefits (healthcare, retirement, tuition benefits) are great, perhaps to compensate for salaries that are below market value.
cons: There is little opportunity for meaningful professional development or promotion and pay is low, so there is little incentive to stay. It also seems that senior administration is out of touch with students, faculty, and staff. There is zero transparency in terms of management and communication between units is frustratingly garbled.

pros: This all depends on which department you are in. I was blessed with a great, sociable department with fun, smart staff. I had a good work-life balance and also took advantage of AU's tuition remission program.
cons: No room for advancement! Also, a lot of staff apply internally for other positions at the university and are not given priority. Lots of people with part-time or temporary jobs, because AU doesn't want to pay for the other benefits. Their new system of giving people bonuses is also not great.

job_title: Graduate Programs Coordinator in Washington, DC
pros: Among some of the best things about working at American University are the work-life balance, the opportunities to meet friendly people and the interactive community. Students are engaging, professors are genuine, and the school is on the cutting edge of professional development.
cons: Due to the small number of jobs, there isn't a lot of  room to move even once you have acquired more professional skills. Also, there is very little to no interaction between programs, they are very isolated. As well, a lot of turnover.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Washington, DC
pros:
-Good retirement benefits 
-Free-ish education
cons:
-Terrible, terrible pay 
-Awful review system
-Elitist

review_title: Positive work experience for undergrads with math skills.
pros: Working in the math tutoring lab allows for flexible hours, time off when needed, and a higher pay, lower stress job overall than most undergrads can expect elsewhere.  All that's required is basic familiarity with math courses through Calculus II.
cons: The student body is accustomed to passing classes without significant effort.  I cannot begin to count the number of times I have had to dismiss a problem student who felt entitled to complain about not receiving an "A," despite showing little mastery of the coursework.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: I was a research assistant for a professor in the International Development program. It was a wonderful opportunity to gain academic research experience and the opportunity to publish.
cons: The pay was not great, as a graduate research assistant there were few benefits/ perks different from being a graduate student at the university. The work load followed the academic calendar in intensity. It always seemed to amp up around the end of the semester as everything else was getting hectic and busy as well. I don't think this is avoidable in an academic setting though.

pros: The campus is beautiful and the students are often really enjoyable to work with. There's a lot of support provided by fellow employees, which creates a close community and supportive culture.
cons: The leadership occasionally doesn't listen or have empathy for all employees. Part-time and lower-level staff aren't really considered by the upper management, depending on where you are. Salaries are not competitive, though benefits are good, particularly if you work full-time and want to take classes. There's not a great work-life balance here, and there are a lot of politics from the top.

pros:
Flexible work hours for faculty
Support for faculty research
cons:
As term faculty, no job security - on a 1-year contract
Terrible salary even if you have a doctorate
Term faculty at bottom of hierarchy

review_title: It's hit or miss and very dependent upon which office you're working in. Public Safety was a train wreck.
pros: Benefits, such as tuition remission, medical, etc.
cons: So many cons at Public Safety. The staff have horrible attitudes about work with many employees consistently trying to push work off on anyone but themselves. There is a revolving door of employees as very few people can stand to work there for more than a year. Constant call-offs mean employees are frequently held over or working alone. The call-offs are so egregious that people in the department seem to view it as vacation time. When I left there were less than five policies and procedures in place. In fact, the department--yes, a university POLICE department--had completely thrown out all former policies and procedures and functioned for almost a year with no policies and procedures in place.

review_title: Hire PT staff and use it like a trash avoiding paying for benefits
pros: I cannot think of any.
cons: Second rate university and second rate staff.  Job descriptions are not updated if there are any.  Long time staff don't want to adept to changing environment.   Hire lots of part time staff compared with other universities in the area because they don't want to pay for benefits.  27 hour a week cap for a part time and they eliminated their positions without any notice.

pros: After working in the private sector for many years, it was interesting and informative to teach at the university and graduate school level.
cons: While there are pros and cons to working at any academic institution, American University has specific organizational problems that need to be addressed before AU is ready to compete at the level of higher education to which they aspire. It seems the new President - Sylvia Burwell - is addressing some of these problems head on.  But she has her work cut out for her, so it remains to be seen what impact she can have in the next few years.

review_title: Easy job - doesn't necessarily lead you anywhere
job_title: Support Technician Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: In my role, work is super conditional. You probably won't have to help most people on most days, but there are some days when events or conferences are happening that require a bit more attention. Most days, I worked on homework or applied for things while on the clock.
cons: You hardly get the chance to learn things. If you ask to help out the Hub as much as you can, you'll still find yourself looking for things to do. So, if you thought this could potentially lead to some career development or growth within AU, you are probably barking up the wrong tree.

review_title: Great University to Pay for your education
pros: The employee benefits package really is great with the Tuition Remission being among the best available at such a high level educational institution. Also, the neighborhood is good and the people are generally great to work with.
cons: The people you will work for are mostly incompetent or at least too overworked to get anything done well.  The campus environment does not seem to care about it's employees either and if you do not work for an office that provides a direct service to students, you might as well work in any other generic office.

review_title: Great place to learn and grow your skills!
pros: As most of the jobs at this department are largely catered to undergrad students, the full-time professional staff are very lenient with the students under their purview. This allows for an awesome learning experience for those who seek to improve themselves and go up the ranks through the three-tiered system.
cons: There are some of the student workers who have clearly not drunk the Kool-Aid and lack motivation, but that's to be expected with student jobs. Upper-level management also seems to lack the creativity and adaptability that is needed when operating on a college campus.

review_title: Excellent Experience But Your Mileage May Vary
pros: I worked as a Graduate Assistant and was matched to a terrific professor who encouraged and supported me.  I can't imagine trying to figure out the literature of my field without the experience doing lit reviews and working through the publishing process with her.
cons: As my title says, your mileage may vary. American University has many jobs, and even different graduate assistants have very different experiences. Advocate for your interests and, if you realize that it really isn't working, then talk to your department about getting a new placement. You really need to self advocate.

pros: Pretty good benefits and nice working environment.
cons: There were some significant issues in communications, processes, and knowledge management. There also wasn't a good career development process. It was also not always clear how and why certain people were promoted and others weren't, as well as clear boundaries in responsibilities and relationships to supervisors. Lot of turnover. This may be only representative of the financial office that I was working in and not reflective of the university at large.

review_title: No room for innovation, lack of leadership, high churn rate
pros: Somewhat flexible, coworkers are great, great benefits with tuition benefits and match program
cons: AU Development team is not a great place for POCs, talk about diversity and inclusion but do not put it into practice, wouldn't recommend it for POCs. No room for growth. Leadership is very averse to suggestions especially if you are a non-white junior/mid-level.

review_title: Good place to work but virtually no room for career adavncement
pros: American University is a great place to work. I love the flexibility in terms of working hours that I have been given to handle my academic and private life. Additionally, AU is very generous in supporting you with your family obligations and care. The work atmosphere is also generally calm and most co-workers are friendly. It is certainly not a high pressure environment as it can be in a corporate enterprise. The university is also advancing in size incredibly fast which is a clear sign of prosperity and growth. Job stability is also very high at AU. Micro management is generally not of concern at AU since you the existing culture expects you to act like an adult and manage your duties responsibly . I must say that it has been a great experience working at AU and I am grateful for the support I have received to advance my academic goals and support my family during hardship.
cons: The biggest problem with AU is career advancement. I have seen many individuals moving up because of who they know and not because of what they know. Many of these individuals do not meet the qualifications necessary to fulfill their jobs and due to this are unable to mitigate problems or adequately handle their issues when they arise. As a result of the poor selection of candidates the entire AU community has to pay the price in terms of services. This is a huge problem in the Information Technology department. The entire community suffers because of incompetent and untalented people that are running essential services that are heavily relied on daily by the entire AU community. Moreover, the CIO gives too much weight and importance to the a single group in the Information Technology  department and allows them to call all the shots. This would be fine if the group leader was competent, however, the leader you have right now is a fake and he doesn't have a clue about what he is doing and implements thing improperly that ends up affecting everyone.  This individual should be fired asap. In addition, there are some legacy technologies that are still running at AU largely due to individuals who are comfortable with where they are and don't possess the knowledge, talent, or desire to move on to 21st century solutions. This results in unnecessary work for other groups and poor quality of service to the rest of the community.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: American University is one of the premiere institutions in Washington, DC. Professors are extremely knowledgeable, and provide a great working environment for research projects.
cons: The University administration has a disappointing level of contempt for students. All of the decent resources available to students and faculty, from the Wellness Center to the Kay Spiritual Center, are provided at a large cost to the excellent folks who provide those services. AU does not care about its student workers beyond the tuition they receive.

review_title: Great place for students to work
pros: I really enjoy working at AU for the people and because my own supervisor has been fantastic. I've  expanded my skills and experience far beyond anything I'd done before. The pay is also pretty good for a grad student like myself. I also loved being able to work on campus so that I didn't have to commute to school.
cons: Some of the offices you have to deal with have a lot of issues that they're constantly working out. Sometimes it's difficult to move up into a full-time position or to get promotions.

review_title: Politics and Pressure in the Office of Campus Life
job_title: Coordinator In Housing and Dining in Washington, DC
pros: 2:1 match up to 5.0% on 403(b); tuition remission benefits; 35-hour work week
cons: politics; cronyism; glass ceiling; low wages at entry level; low employee morale; high turnover; shifty time sheet reporting; antiquated software and systems; parking prices (>$1400/year); "Welcome to AU administration... we need you to bilk these students..."

review_title: Good place to work, great benefits and community
pros: Great benefits, 9-5 schedule with an hour lunch break, health and fitness programs for staff, interesting and challenging work (depending on what you do and environment). People are great. It's a nice friendly community and the campus is lovely.
cons: Limited growth opportunities for some positions, some people have been at the same jobs for many years and are set in their ways so younger staff may not always get their ideas heard. Culture shift from more laid back to more aggressive and almost corporate feel in some departments.

review_title: The pay isn't great, but AU cares about employees and this is reflected in benefits, bonuses, and employee services
pros: As a graduate student, the pay is fairly good and they were incredible flexible, supportive and understanding. The location is great and they encourage me to take time off to study or finish exams. They also helped me look for jobs and understood that I would eventually leave the office
cons: Considering the cost of tuition, the pay could be better and the parking could be more flexible.

pros: Most departments have a relaxed working atmosphere, and don't micromanage. You are trusted to complete your own work on time.
cons: It can be incredibly difficult to complete cross-department projects, due to lack cohesion and foresight. The left hand rarely knows (or cares) what the right hand is doing.

review_title: Caring about both staff and students
pros: AU has great benefits, including tuition remission and a 2-for-1 match on up to a 5% donation to your 403 (b) retirement account. All the staff whom I work with truly value and care about the students.
cons: There is, of course, internal politics, and the management skill can very from department to department.   At its worst, upper level academicians may make decisions without collaborating/ seeking consensus with offices that may be impacted by those decisions.

pros: flexible hours, connects you to other people on campus, looks good on a resume, ability to do homework during shifts so that you can work and study at the same time
cons: incompetent management, poor training, unrealistic expectations. you will never get a pay raise. you will be forced to work hours that are inconvenient and you have to work on holidays when you'd much rather be spending time at home.

review_title: Don Myers is an excellent place for student assistants to work alongside their future intellectual peers.
pros: The wages and hours are very considerate. The employers respected that education comes first before the work study job, yet always treated the student assistants with the same appreciation and respect as the full-time employees. The Don Myers building is an excellent work ambiance as well.
cons: Commuting to AU from out of town can be difficult, as the campus is a little ways from Tenleytown metro, but the shuttle beats walking.

pros: 2 for 1 retirement matching.  Tuition remission. Week off between Christmas and New Year's.  The grounds' team keeps the campus looking amazing.
cons: The distribution of work is demoralizing - and many of those who do relatively little get ongoing promotions and raises while those that are doing the work of two people are underpaid and under-appreciated.  High turnover.  Pay disparity.  Lack of professional development opportunities.   Staff are treated like second-class citizens compared to faculty.

pros: AU embraces multiculturalism and progressiveness wholeheartedly. It is a quiet and pretty campus on the outskirts of Washington, DC. The university is also very committed to be socially and environmentally conscious.
cons: While the university offers a lot of benefits to staff, its pay is not as competitive as it could be. Staff between departments don't necessarily know each other, outside of those offices your work requires direct interaction. This is somewhat due to a culture of people either staying only 2-5 years or over 20 years.

pros:
Great Benefits and Leave Package 
Friendly Work Environment 
Staff Appreciation Week is awesome.
cons:
Not much room to get a promotion, AU would rather spend lots of money on the search process rather than hire internally. 
Pay is rather low, and they pay you for 7 hours when you are required to be at work for 8 hours

review_title: Research Assistant, willing to lend a hand
pros: Access to top notch software, ability to be flexible with hours. They helped a ton with setting up expensive software suites on my laptop so that I would be able to work from home. I loved every minute of working as a Research Assistant and definitely got a lot of benefits as a young professional from the experience. Would recommend.
cons: Occassionally, employing professors are not understanding of "student hours" though I think I ended up with a great professor who was more than understanding.

review_title: Very satisfactory, everyone is very kind and helpful. I feel like a part of the team.
pros: As a grad assistant, my schedule is very flexible and the pay is very good. I feel like I an cater the job to my needs and I also feel like I am gaining some good work experience.
cons: From my personal experience and because I have not been working there long, nothing truly negative comes to mind. This might be a different case for someone who has worked longer than I.

job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Alexandria, VA
pros: Everyone is so happy!  Benefits are unbelievable, especially if you take advantage of them.  Lots of tools and trainings available to develop leadership or professional skills.  Beautiful campus, if your office is nearby.
cons: With such a satisfied workforce, no one leaves, so there are few opportunities for growth.  Many positions are very slow at least 6 months out of the year - (which may be a pro for some people, esp if you want to take classes).

pros: Friendly co-workers, good health and retirement benefits, lots of opportunities for education on campus.
cons: Academic staff is not valued by faculty or Dean's level. Even though we do the most hands on work with students our opinions and experiences are given little credibility. Very low pay.

review_title: AU Library is a positive place to work
job_title: Library Course Reserves Assistant in Washington, DC
pros:
Good teams and support within teams
Supervisors are responsible and help employees gain as many skills as they can
Opportunities to work in all departments, not just the one you're hired for
cons:
The bureaucracy is a little bit nuts, but this is mostly an issue for the highest-ups in the organization.
Oodles of panicked students on exam days.

pros:
Friendly work environment - like family
flexible hours to your class schedule
can be fun at times
free food sometimes especially in the summer
can add or drop hours when needed
cons:
high stress at times
sometimes it feels like you are blamed for something you didn't do
learned everything I could in the first few months
repetitive
capped pay at 15$/hr

job_title: Senior Finance Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: The benefits (retirement especially) are pretty great. There are incentives and events for staff that make you feel included and part of a bigger family. Students are driven and inspiring.
cons: Location in DC makes it hard in terms of commuting. HR is chronically understaffed which makes certain processes difficult. In my department there was a lot of turnover which hindered our work and did not help with morale.  Lack of diversity is also a negative factor for staff morale.

pros: I really enjoyed working at American University, and stayed several years because of the great culture and mission-driven values of the university. Very much so a university leading the way for student enrichment and success!
cons: Not a lot of room for growth once you move into middle-level management because it is a smaller private institution, and the folks in senior-level positions tend to stay in their positions a long time (there is the good and bad in that!).

pros: The student jobs are prolific and a job in Housing means you can work around the clock, unrestricted by 9-5 working hours.
cons: You will be told you are a "student first", but no one cares about your personal growth or the value you carry away from a job. Benefits (such as "free housing") will be counted as university grants by the university aid office rather than as compensation for a job, resulting in a corresponding plummet in your aid.

review_title: Good Place to Work, but Challenging Administration
pros: Faculty and other workers are engaged and excellent. Many are immediately interested in learning and helping co-workers.
cons: The administration is impossible to work with. The past several years they have been setting up more and more barriers between the administrators who are able to make descisions and the employees and students.

review_title: Positive movement eclipsed by "one size fits all" new culture.
pros:
strong faculty
strong students
work hours
good benefits
great location
some good faculty development opportunities
excellent art museum
multi university consortium/library is helpful.
cons:
lack of respect for individual programs and needs
changed culture is not a good fit for everyone
too much emphasis on raising revenue and competing in areas that are not strengths of the school
many poor administrators who are not held accountable for bad management and poor decisions
vague and erratically applied tenure and promotion criteria

review_title: Do it for the love of the work...
job_title: Educator, Part Time in Washington, DC
pros: It's a great place to encourage others to  follow their passion.  There's a special energy about being on a college campus.
cons: It always surprises me that students are charged so much and teachers are paid so little. As tih many part time positions, there are no benefits...and no raises.

review_title: People and environment great, pay not so great
pros: Good school, nice employees, socially conscious and smart students
cons: Pays terribly. Too many part-time positions that are not eligible for benefits.

pros: benefits, retirement plan, closed between Christmas and New Years, beautiful campus, friendly people, comfortable dress code, seated massage, farmers market on campus (sometimes)
cons: parking is expensive. metro is far from campus. food options are closed during the summer. Not much healthy/affordable food on campus.

review_title: I wish I could spend more time doing this but I have other stuff to do
job_title: Reference and Instruction Librarian Part-Time in Washington, DC
pros:
Easy to commute to by bus, walking or metro
sick benefits for p-t workers (maybe?...did not try to use them)
cons: It's weird sometimes. I feel left out. Also holiday parties have bad desserts, especially pecan bars.

pros: Graduate Assistantships being awarded at all is a huge plus. Performance expectations were low. You do research whenever you want to, just show up to your weekly meeting - the ultimate flex hours as it were.
cons: Depends entirely on the professor to whom you are assigned, I imagine. Most projects are pretty dry and tedious, and you probably don't have a lot of room for injecting your own creativity. No benefits for part-time RA.

pros: General experience depends on the professor you work with, provides the opportunity to develop a mentorship or get more involved in a class you find particularly interesting, also it pays pretty well for menial work.
cons: AU is terrible about getting the first paycheck to undergraduate TAs. After that it's not terrible, but they need to understand that we're students.

review_title: Don't work with money at AU
pros: Education benefits, 401k matching, diverse workforce.
cons: Internal customers can be demeaning, pushy, rude, and bullying staff into making policy exceptions.  Certain policies are rarely enforced.  Where policies are enforced, expect major push back from employees.   A general disregard of fiscal responsibilities.  Changes, even positive ones, take years to be green-lighted for implementation.

pros: Nice campus; intelligent and diverse study body; good benefits package including generous retirement benefits;
cons: Low pay; morale is very low among staff; high turnover; a lot of intrapersonal drama and conflict among senior staff which contributes to a general culture of competition rather than collaboration.

pros:
Tuition Remission- Discounted tuition is Gold! 
The university is nationally and internationally recognized and respected. 
Location in DC is great
cons: Not much opportunity for professional or career advancement. There is an obvious divide between faculty, staff and students where staff lie lowest on the totem pole.

pros: One of the best benefit packages around, specifically the 2 to 1 retirement matching. Encourages continuing education. Academic setting is stimulating.
cons: Difficult to adjust to bureaucracy after working at a smaller company, lack of communication among various levels of bureaucracy

review_title: Socially awkward, hard working, looks good on resume.
pros: Close to the city, and if you find the right people, you can go out once in a while. Many varieties of international mixes. Good rep for the school... hard work towards your degree.
cons: Socially awkward people. No places to live but the Berks. Expensive. Should I order in every night or eat the soggy cafe food?

pros: The people are wonderful to work for and with. They create a supportive culture and are always there to help with anything you need to make it easier to do your job.
cons: The big con is the nature of being an adjunct more so than AU in particular. You never know when or if you'll be teaching from semester to semester. The uncertainty can be stressful.

pros: Got myself a free MA degree. The benefits are amazing. Retirement matching is 2:1.  People mostly leave at 5PM, allowing great work life balance. I enjoyed my job managing an international program.
cons: I worked at the law school where rankings are tanking. That was a tough time because budgets were cut. If they don't think the rankings are just, they should ignore them, not play into them.

review_title: There is a place here for people with ideas and patience
pros: Nice work-life balance, I had the benefit of working in a unit with seasonal highs and lows.  Plenty of time to study or participate in other campus events.
cons: Bureaucratic as you would expect a university to be.  Parking fees ridiculously high.  HR office is not deployed for the benefit of the staff, but rather to cover the administration's liabilities.

job_title: Program Control Analyst in Washington, DC
pros: love the vitality of the campus and the community.  short of being a student, what better gig than to work on a campus?
cons: one could always hope for a better salary, and AU should do more to improve retention of employees with a strong benefits package and other opportunities to advance.

job_title: Program Specialist Key Executive Leadership Program in Washington, DC
pros: Depending on the department you work in, the at work benefits are great. Lots of free food. All speakers and events are open to staff. Gym membership is only $16 month. HR is very helpful for Short Term Disability Issues
cons: Parking is very frustrating and the policies are always changing. The medical benefits are the bare minimum and you accrue leave rather than start off with all of your PTO.

pros: Working in this office was great for a student while still providing for development of professional skills.
cons: Limited hours depending on the office and their budget for student workers beyond the hours provided by federal work study.

review_title: Nice place, but needs an update
pros: Tuition Benefits are flexible and comprehensive
cons: Advancement is difficult, pay lags behind market, HR is far behind the times, especially regarding work-life balance

review_title: Not a bad place to work
pros: Staff is friendly, the students are what you would expect of a private university and generally you are fairly well prepared for your work.
cons: Sometimes the opinion of the university doesn't seem to match up with the actual prestige of the school. Additionally sometimes the expectations of student staff are high, particularly when considering that you are required to take a full course load.

review_title: Good place to work as a student
pros: Better than average starting salary. Able to speak to alumni and gain insight on opportunities after graduation.
cons: Hours for shifts are very inflexible. The job can get tiresome, and can be unpleasant depending on who you're speaking with.

review_title: Great academic environment, but management doesn't much care about you professionally
job_title: PhD Student and Graduate Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: Supportive academic environment; interdisciplinary applied research; good collaboration with DC universities and federal agencies; recent unionization of graduate student workers
cons: Overarching management is dismissive of graduate student workers; pay for graduate student assistantships is relatively low and benefits are non-existent; not much recognition that graduate students have lives outside of the university because many faculty administrators believe they shouldn't

pros: great environment, great people, great benefits, supervisors really care about the welfare of research staff and try to make sure that their needs are met.
cons: maybe more room for advancement should be provided to research fellows, fellows should be started out at a higher pay grade.

review_title: The experience fully revolves around the competency of your direct superior and the room for professional growth.
pros: At American University, there's the tuition remission program, which is always an added incentive for working for a university. The staff are also very very friendly.
cons: It's sometimes a bit more casual than in a corporate environment where you're constantly dealing with competition and the economic success of your company.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty Member in Washington, DC
pros: Teaching and learning, universities are nice places.
cons:
Overblown bureaucracy, lots of superfluous highly paid administrators and assistant this and that. Half (!) of all undergraduate teaching is done by adjuncts.  Total salary payout to all adjuncts: less than 2% of total revenue. How ethical is that? 
 AU chooses to severely underpay hundreds of Professors. Why?  Because they can.

pros:
Great benefits package. Tuition remission also helps if you want to take classes. Have access to a lot of school amenities at little to no cost.
Spouses & children can take advantage of tuition remission.
cons: Avenues for advancement can be limited in some departments where the.

job_title: Public Safety Aide in Washington, DC
pros: Easy to apply , federal work study friendly, good coworkers, teaches you customer service, good pay, sometimes you meet famous people who come to American U
cons: Minimal skills gained, not much professional development gain, people that you give tickets to can be very mean, limited hours

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Washington, DC
pros:
-fairly easy
-very flexible hours (desk operational 24/7 so you have a lot of freedom to work a different job or internship between 9-5 and still maintain hours)
-good pay
-lots of opportunity to move up
cons:
-can seem like the people in charge do not care about the employee point of view
-change takes years
-slow decision making

job_title: TALK Program Coordinator in Washington, DC
pros: Intimate campus; international students and staff; progressive values; beautiful facilities; a sense of community
cons: Some graduate student positions are not adequately compensated

pros: The pay was pretty good and the mission of the office was important to the university
cons: leadership very poor.  Unusual benefits restrictions, i.e., you cannot always use sick leave if you are sick.

pros: Working in higher education is very rewarding.  You have great benefits such as tuition remission and are always meeting new students and faculty.
cons: There really aren't any. If you love people and students and don't mind hard work with a lower disposable income, this would be a great job for you.

pros: Amazing location, opportunities are endless thanks to its location and professors brought in, wonderful career center with advice and there are helpful advisors
cons: It is a bureaucracy - if you aren't able to network don't bother coming here, however, this is a great temp job for people looking to pay for college an affordable way through working as staff!

pros: Fantastic colleagues. Diverse, smart and motivated students. Just the right size for a higher education community.
cons: Top level decisions are not as transparent as they are advertised to be. The classroom and meeting facilities are sub-par. I'm concerned about students' debt levels.

review_title: Worked here as a graduate student and had an excellent experience!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: Very supportive of graduate student workers involved in research. Encouraging of new opportunities and growth.
cons: I did not feel that there were any major cons to working here, except that the pay is a bit low for graduate level work, but I imagine this is the case anywhere.

pros: Freedom to create a syllabus based on my professional experience as a graphic designer and art director. Allowing me to teach skills relevant to what an employer is seeking in the real world.
cons: I can honestly say there were no cons to the position. The resources and environment were supportive to my teaching style.

pros: Great people to work with, depending on the department. There's always something new and exciting going on.
